Hovey — 2
There is in Italy today a genuine and growing fear about the
direction of tbm United States foreign policy.
How widespread It is in the country I would not attempt to say
on the basis of a residence of only two months to date.
But what makes it worth reporting, it seems to me, is that an
American finds this fear in Italian circles where he least expects
it. He finds gnawing doubts about American objectives and even
American motives. In many cases, distrust would not be too strong
a word.
For this particular American, this phenomenon is one of the most
striking and impressive aspects of the Italian political landscape.
Never mind, for the moment, what the Communists and their left
Socialist allies say about us; theirs is the same old warmed-over
iioscow-dominform hash, with, to be sure, a few peculiarly Italian
Journalistic and x»h rhetorical touches here and there.
And never mind what Italy*s new and ever-bolder Fascists are
saying about America, though, as I tried to indicate in a previous
letter, what they say is not unimportant in the present Italian
political situation.
what ought to concern us is what our friends are saying; the
people on whom rest the hopes for the survival and strengthening of
Italy * s democracy; the people who have supported our policies in the
past and wish to support us in the future.
These are the Italians who find their political outlets in the
parties of the Center and moderate Left; the parties that made up
the old coalition of former Premier Ale id e de Casper! for most of these
postwar years j the Christian Democrats, Social Democrats, Republicans
and Liberals.
